body.description: He has endured more than any child ever should, but now he must survive Block 66.January, 1945. 14-year-old Moshe Kessler steps off the train at Buchenwald concentration camp. Having endured the horrors of Auschwitz-Birkenau, lost touch with his entire family, and survived the death march in the freezing European winter, he has seen more than his share of tragedy.Moshe knows only one thing about Buchenwald. Everyone knows it.If you want to survive, you have to get to Block 66.The Germans are cruel and determined – but they are not prepared for Buchenwald’s secret resistance, which rises up with one mission only: to protect the camp’s children from harm.This is the incredible true story of Moshe Kessler and Block 66 – the children’s block that was at the forefront of one of the most shocking and inspiring stories of Holocaust survival. Read more

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 5, 2024
reviews.reviewText: This book is a narrative of one man's experience from early in his childhood, through his time as a captive of the Germans at age 13. He describes the horrors he survived during WWII and continues with his after war life. His description of his feelings and sensory experience throughout are clear and explanatory. All people should read this book to explain to themselves how hatred and power can can be devastating, if allowed to exist and grow. It is a lesson to be learned as a preventative to future evil and a reminder of how life, itself, can easily be destroyed.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 11, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars A must read for anyone interested in the Holocaust.
reviews.reviewText: The gripping story of a Holocaust survivor. The inhuman treatment of these innocent people by the Germans is tragic. This book is particularly pertinent because the story is told by a survivor who was a young boy and his will to survive the atrocities and brutal treatment despite his tender age.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 25, 2024
reviews.reviewText: This book started slow for me only because it has so much political history to absorb in the beginning. It was an interesting read due to it being from a child’s experiences and not that of an adult like most of the Holocaust biographies. I would recommend.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 7, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Critical history book on the plight of european jewish
reviews.reviewText: Just started reading yesterday. Very good book, and a critical documentation of what a family in ever-changing Europe (Czech, hungary, poland,germany,..) of the early 1900s affected jewish peoples lives...

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 7, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Eye Opening Book
reviews.reviewText: A good but sad read that really opens your eyes to what happened during the Holocaust. Would recommen it. It is a short read but good.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 1, 2024
reviews.reviewText: While difficult to believe that such atrocities happened, they did. This is a walk through one families trials and challenges. Never Forget this DID happen and learn from the past.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 5, 2024
reviews.reviewText: At the same time it's unbelievably shocking, yet leaves the reader hunger for more. The children of tragedy possess survival instincts that most adults lack.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 23, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 3.0 out of 5 stars An important read
reviews.reviewText: I feel like as a true story about the Holocaust it's important to read. I did feel like a lot of what the author went through was glossed over and generalized, which is understandable as a victim. I did find it interesting that there were not one, but several instances where he had to make choices in the moment that saved his life. I don't believe I would have been that lucky or had that intuition.

Read this book and you will stop complaining about your life. We have no idea what is to live a difficult life and what hell on earth really is. Read and you will have an idea, but still it is unimaginable what those innocent people lived. I can't describe how I felt reading this book and how I still feel about it. Atrocious, barbaric, gruesome, shocking, horrific, abominable, outrageous. The most shocking is that all this mass murder of innocent people went on for years and the rest of the world and most European countries consented to that. How much more barbaric can this get? My huge respect to those who risked their lives to save some of them. Unfortunately, millions were gone for just being who they were. Nothing else. I'm not even someone religious and religion is the opium of the people, but murdering innocent people just because they are from a religious group is barbaric, criminal, atrocious. Those who envied the hardworking prosperous Jewish people should have just worked as hard as them instead of trying to get rid of them. Envy is the most harmful emotion. Empathy is the most important one, but few are really empathetic. Very sad.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on February 2, 2024
reviews.reviewText: So very touching brought to tears. Amazing pictures at the end, thank you. Simple to follow. Shall we never forget

reviews.reviewTitle: History is the most important lesson!
reviews.reviewText: Well written book about a very important subject.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on January 2, 2024
reviews.reviewText: Great quality and a good read
